_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This facility complies with the Chlorine Institute and the Florida Department of Environmental Protection requirements for chlorine gas storage, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to contact the City of Apopka Fire Communications dispatcher, at 911 or 407-703-1757 and request emergency response. The area leak detection equipment is connected to the facility SCADA system that immediately contacts the Fire Department in the event of leak detection for emergency assistance. The City of Apopka Fire department is equipped with a trained Haz Mat team that is qualified to respond to these types of emergencies.
                                                                                                                                                                                      This facility is a municipal Water Reclamation Facility. Chlorine is used to disinfect our effluent, which is used for public access reuse irrigation. Chlorine is used and stored in 1-ton containers in a covered building next to the chlorination system. The chlorination system consists of up to eight 1-ton containers. This facility uses two tank mounted, vacuum operated regulators with one container feeding at all times and 1 container hooked to the system and ready for automatic switch-over when the container that is feeding empties. In the event of a leak anywhere in the feed system, the regulator will pull a vacuum and stop chlorine feed to the system. 
                                                                                                                                                                                  Worst-case scenario is a release of chlorine from the total failure of a 1-ton cylinder. This event is unlikely to occur and is presented here as required by the Risk Management Program regulations. The EPA's RMP* Comp v.107 calculates the distance endpoint for this quan

tity of chlorine at less than 0.90 miles.
                                                                                                                                                                                      The alternative release scenario is a more realistic accident that would involve a release of gaseous chlorine from, a leaking pipe. This event produces minimal release, as the chlorine gas piping operates under a vacuum and will stop feeding at the moment of vacuum loss. It is estimated that less than one pound of chlorine gas would be released in this scenario. The EPA's RMP*Comp v.107 calculates the distance endpoint for this quantity at less than 0.10 miles.                                                                        This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule, OSHA's PSM rule, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The chlorination system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with the Chlorine Institute and the Florida Department of Environmental Protection state regulations. The operators at the Water Reclamation facility are Florida State certified professionals. To prepare for an emergency, plant operators have been trained in respiratory protection, emergency action, and fire prevention. We have a combined total of over 100 years of experience in safely handling chlorine. They receive updated training regarding operations and safety on a regular basis.
                                                                                                                                                                                     The Apopka Water Reclamation Facility has never had an accident involving chlorine that has caused death, injury, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.
In the event of an emergency involving the chlorination system or the stored chlorine, it is our policy to contact the City of Apopka Fire Communications dispatcher and r

equest emergency response. Additional measures in place include all leak detection equipment is connected to the SCADA system that dials directly to Fire Communications for immediate dispatch. This measure protects manned and unmanned operations. This policy was formulated in cooperation with the City of Apopka Fire Department, and members of the Fire Department have inspected and trained on our chlorination system.
